Duc to the opacity of the living eggs, the details of maturation,
association of the germ nuclei, and cleavage can best be studied from prepared
slides. The eggs are not sectioneu, but are whole mnunts. Number one or zero
cover glasses have been used, making it possitle tu examine the material under
high power. Du not under anv circumstances use oil immersinn ob ectives on
THESE SLIDES. Gonklin's two monographs 1397 ann 1902) may be used for referenc 
or the photo copies of the plates from these papers.
Crepidula is a dioecious genus with the males fewer in number and
smaller than the adult females. The spermatozoa mingle with ova before the egg
capsules are formed around groups uf eggs in the oviouct of the female. The
mature females are sedentary, and the males locomotive, and at the breeding season
or perhaps once for all, the females are visited and inseminated by these motile
males. All of the ova produced by a given individual curing a season are laid
within a short space of time.
l. On the prepared slides, make a careful stuuy of various stages in the two
maturation divisions. In the same eggs find the sperm nucleous ana note its
approach bu the egg nutleus. Note also the small antipclar lobe. Make drawings.
2. Study the first and seccnd cleavages, noting the direction of the axes of the
mitotic figures in the latter. The small antipolar lobe may be visible near the
vegetal region of the furrow at the 2-cell stage. Make drawings.
3. Study in detail the formation of the first three quartettes of mifromeres and
the formation of the derivatives of the first and secenn quartettes. Indicate
which divisions are dexitropic and which are leiotropic. Fine ana draw examples
and 25~cel1 stages. The last is difficult to find and
it should be checked carefully. The nuclei be identified by their size
characteristics.
Some students, in their spare time, may wish to prepare their own slices
of Crepicula maturation and cleavage stages. The following method is suggested:
A. Obtaining with a heavy knife, loosen a Erepiuula shell from its
attachment. The egg capsules will either be attached to the substrate or to the
foot of the female. Those that are small and light yellow contain eggs in the
earlier stages of development; the larger, deep yellow or mud-colored capsules
contain older embryos and larvae. Remove the capsules, by means of forceps, to
a of sea water. Tear open the capsules with a pair of needles to
release the eggs. Discard empty capsules. Examine the eggs under the microscope
to ascertain the stage. Dark-fielu illumination may be helpful. lt is best to
mix several batches of young stages for slide-making.
B. Fixgtinn; (Do not use fixatives or other reagents in any uishes which are
used for living materials. (Confine these reagents to vials). Having freed the
eggs, wash them by gentle rotary rinsing with a pipette, and then concentrate them
in the center of the cish. Change the sea water two or three times. Then take
up the concentrates eggs with a pipette, and drop them, with a small amount of
sea water, into a vial three~quarters full of Kleinenberg's picro-sulphuric
fixative. The eggs should be fixed at least 15 minutes.
Remove the fixative, using a pipette of small diameter equipped with a
